Nevertheless it is our hope that, during the period of this grant, many
mistakes were prevented, many technical installations and program centers
were improved, and many fine standards were set which would otherwise have
been impossible. Even if only briefly, one danger area in ETV, as recognized
by all concerned, was served with, we hope, both distinction and integrity.
We are grateful for the privilege of having been enabled to do this
much, and hope that, in the critical years ahead, we may in some way
assist in the establishment of equipment, building and other standards which
will insure against the type of obsolescence and waste of public and other
funds which lack of knowledge, or a central cleaning house for such tech¬
nical data, left as a legacy to educational radio — a legacy which plagues
it and American education even today.
Placement Service
When educational television stations began operation in increasing
numbers they needed a central clearing house through which they might find
the best possible employees. The many men and women interested in ETV
as a career also needed an agency to which they could turn to learn what
jobs might be available in their chosen field. Early efforts to meet this
need were made by the NCCET, which, however, did not feel qualified to
